author: ajsutton
content:
Given the available blob space was just increased by a third I’d be very worried if that was all consumed again already. There’s a lot of factors to how many blobs per tx you’d want to send - more blobs amortises the execution cost more but means it takes longer to fill up that data and thus the chain safe head updates less often. And if you’re submitting a block with the full limit of blobs it can’t fit alongside any other blob tx which can delay inclusion (less so now but was a challenge prior to pectra). I believe there may be some block builders that don’t include blob tx as well which makes it appear as if more capacity is available than there actually is (also really only noticeable pre pectra). 
Finally because the blob base fee is so low it actually makes it very slow to increase so even when there is temporary congestion for blobs the price doesn’t increase fast.

author: ajsutton
content:
One of the nice things about Pectra is that the blob increase makes a lot of these factors less complex to work with largely because there is much less need for L2s to fill the full target of blobs in the txs they send which leaves room for blob tx to fit beside each other more and thus use the available capacity better. 
But mostly we really expect there should be spare capacity currently and as the rate of tx on L2s continues to grow we’ll see that fill up.

author: tersec
content:
In the meantime, maybe it's a good time to align economic incentives between proposers and blob users: https://ethresear.ch/t/max-blobs-flag-economic-perspective/21798 shows
> Local builders earn an average of 0.0233 ETH in priority fees per block. Excluding Type-3 transactions could reduce EL profits by approximately 1.2% to 1.5%. For bandwidth-constrained proposers, this trade-off may be justified if it improves block propagation and lowers the risk of reorgs.

author: tersec
content: A network without such aligned incentives is more fragile precisely because it is entirely rational, in a way that's not true for any other validation component, for a proposer to deliberately use a flag such as `--max-blobs` and undermine the design

author: tersec
content: The only real shield here is the power of defaults and ignorance/inability of most users to make these changes

author: ajsutton
content: L2s don’t really have a choice about whether to submit or not. What we found when blobs were congested was it just became extremely difficult to get blob tx included at all at any price. The OP Stack batcher can bump gas prices quite aggressively to get transactions included but it didn’t help much. Partly because the blob base fee responds quite slowly and partly because blobs dont always fit (eg couldn’t have a 3 blob tx and a 4 blob tx in the same block)

author: ajsutton
content: The transaction rates on L2 would sometimes need to be throttled because of the inability to get blobs on chain in a timely manner causing unsubmitted data to back up and get dangerously large.

author: tersec
content: My other question would be, what was the mechanism by which it took from March to October 2024 for L2s to figure out how to consistently target exactly 3 blobs/block as a running average?

author: fradamt
content: It can never be over the target consistently, because fees will rise and users will stop sending txs, it's not like they actively need to be doing anything to stay below the target. And as for consuming the target, they just didn't have enough usage before

author: sanleo
content:
There's no mechanism 
If the blob fee consistently remains above the minimum (1 wei), then the avg blobs per block will always eventually round out to 3, it can never consistently remain above 3 over a large timescale, else the fee will skyrocket

If the blob fee is 1 wei, then avg blobs/block will always be <=3
